How to Apply for a Course

For entry to full-time undergraduate courses an application must be made through the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS). This is the central admissions service for all universities and colleges of higher education in the UK. The easiest way to apply through UCAS is by accessing the UCAS website www.ucas.com and using the online system "apply".
The UCAS deadline for submission of applications is 15 January of the year in which you wish to enter. However
column2: the University will accept Abertay course applications at any time prior to commencement of the course
column3: subject to availability of places. The UCAS code for the University of Abertay Dundee is A30 ABTAY and the individual UCAS course codes are shown in each course description in the prospectus. View the Prospectus online here.

column1: Applications for part-time and postgraduate courses should be made direct to the University using our Abertay course application form. The application form is available from the Student Recruitment Office or you can download it here. The completed form (with references and photocopies of academic transcript/certificates) should be sent to Registry (Admissions) at the University.
If in any doubt about which admissions procedure to use please contact the Student Recruitment Office who will be pleased to advise you.

The University deals with all applications upon receipt and we aim to advise you of our decision as soon as possible. Advice of the outcome of each application will come from either UCAS (in the case of applications through the UCAS system) or direct from the University
column2: and the response will normally be one of the following:

column1: Under certain circumstances the University may offer the opportunity to join a waiting list.
You should note that a small number of our courses have a slightly different admissions system. For example
column2: our BSc (Hons) (pre-reg) Nursing applicants are interviewed prior to a decision being made
column3: and our BA (Hons) Computer Arts applicants are asked to attend an interview and also provide a portfolio.

column1: If you have been given a conditional offer and do not achieve the required grades
column2: we would recommend you contact us as you may still be considered for your original course choice or there may be an alternative available.
you may ask to receive feedback on your application. Details of how to do this can be downloaded here.
the University will use a range of criteria to make an assessment of your application. Details of the criteria taken into consideration can be downloaded here.

column1: The University is happy to accept applications for admission to a later session for which applications would normally be made. For example
column3: your application would normally be for entry in September 2007
column6: for entry in September 2008. If you wish to apply for deferred entry
column7: please make this clear on the application form.

column1: Although applicants are advised to apply as early as possible (the final deadline for UCAS is 30 June) it is still possible
column3: to apply up until the start of the course (Mid September). Those applying for the first time during July-September of the year of entry should contact the Student Recruitment Office for advice on course availability
column4: and on the correct application procedure.

column2: enrolment to courses of the University is
column4: open to all those who have the ability to benefit from the opportunity. All applications to the University will be considered on an equal basis in line with the University’s Equal Opportunities Policy. The University will not discriminate on the grounds of age
column9: gender or sexual orientation. You can download a full copy of the Admissions Policy here.

column1: Fraudulent Applications Policy

The University reserves the right at any stage to request applicants and enrolling students to provide additional information about any aspect of their application or enrolment. In the event of any student providing false or inaccurate information at any stage
column2: and/or failing to provide additional information when requested to do so
column3: the University further reserves the right to withdraw an application
column6: and demand payment of any fees or monies due to the University.

column1: All applicants are required to sign a declaration on the application form certifying that the information provided is correct.
Applicants and their referees in the UCAS system are required to sign a declaration that states:
I confirm that the information given on this form is true
column2: complete and accurate and no information requested or other material information has been omitted. I have read How to Apply. I undertake to be bound by the terms set out in it and I give my consent to the processing of my data by UCAS and educational establishments. I accept that
column3: if I do not comply with these requirements
column4: UCAS shall have the right to cancel my application and I shall have no claim against UCAS or any higher education institution or college in relation thereto.

column1: Direct applicants to the University are required to sign a declaration that states:
I certify that to the best of my knowledge the information given on this form is true
column2: complete and accurate and no information requested or other material information has been omitted and if I am admitted to the University I undertake to observe the University's regulations. I give my consent to the processing of my data by the University. I accept that
column3: if I do not comply with these requirements
column4: the University  shall have the right to cancel my application and I shall have no claim against the University  in relation thereto.

column1: The University takes the issue of fraud very seriously
• Works in conjunction with UCAS to detect fraudulent applications and take the appropriate action
<li>Verifies qualifications including English language qualifications with the appropriate bodies e.g. SQA
• Requires students to show original academic qualification certificates on registration where these have not previously been verified
• Individuals who provide false information to gain a place by deception
• Individuals who aim to secure financial assistance by deception
• Individuals who seek to obtain a student visa for the purposes of entering the UK by deception

UCAS provide the Hunter facility that checks for suspicious applications and alerts all universities of offending applicants. Where an applicant has clearly committed a fraud the application is cancelled for that cycle by UCAS. If an admissions tutor suspects a fraudulent UCAS application this will be referred to UCAS after consultation with the Student Recruitment Office (SRO).

Where fraudulent information is detected relating to a direct application the University will put the application on hold pending a full investigation. If the application is believed to be fraudulent the University may withdraw the application and/or to rescind any offer made (and refuse any future applications from the applicant).
